title: Will Alexei Navalny be imprisoned or placed under house arrest between 10 January 2018 and 8 April 2018?
preds: With a day to go, I'm dropping the percentage  to the temperature in Siberia on a warm day.
Dropping to zero because there's just a couple days left.

It seems very unlikely that he would be arrested in the coming days, although regretfully this could very happen afterwards. For now, the Kremlin will probably not want to draw unwanted attention, especially as they are pressing for a visit to the White House.

Well if AN is in Germany, he's in fear for his life and or he's going to expose more corruption. And Russia/Putina have/has a pretty good record at killing enemies.  Murders made to look like suicides, stabbings, hangings, poisonings etc. It's been nuclear and chemical so far, so maybe another Bulgarian style ricin attack for AN?

Social networks report that Navalny flew to Germany
https://life.ru/t/новости/1103555/navalnyi_v_dni_traura_po_zhiertvam_kiemierovskoi_traghiedii_ulietiel_v_ghiermaniiu_--_vidieo

The Presidential Elections are over in Russia and he was not imprisoned, but wasn't allowed to run which was expected.
There no known demonstration are planned by Navalny, no criminal charges brought against him, his political activity is at bare minimum relegated to Twitter, YouTube and personal website. However knowing Russian Government's oppressive methods against Navalny and the opposition the arrest can never be ruled out.

Putin recently "won" an election. This will continue to embolden him to take actions against anyone that challenges his power.  Recent actions in the UK against former Russian spies, the West's response, and Russia's response to the West will only continue for the near future I think.  At some point in all these events Navalny will say or do something that Putin will feel he has to respond to to indicate he controls the narrative, not anyone else in Russia.

But why? Vlad had an excellent opportunity to lock Navalny up and be able to spin it months ago, yet Moscow 5-0 "botches the paperwork." Now, post-election Vlad's in a world of hurt, locking up Navalny now makes him look weak and reactionary in light of his diplomats getting the boot from US and Europe. Vlad needs a big play now and Navalny's too small of a potato.
Putin is not threatened. Attacking AN is risky in light of the poisoning in Britain. Gary Kasparov is in the same league - too risky to harm.

At the end of January I predicted a 98% chance that Navalny would be imprisoned or placed under house arrest before 8 April 2018. I'm updating this forecast to 17% probability to reflect the fact that the Russian elections have already taken place. Navalny's role in the elections as a public leader of the opposition was arguably the greatest threat to the Kremlin. Since the elections passed and Putin was able to secure another 6 years in office without taking major action against Navalny, I argue that the probability of his arrest is dramatically reduced, especially given the short time period remaining in this question. Further, there has not been any recent major news regarding Navalny, indicating that for the time being he does not have the attention of the government. I still predict a minor chance that he will be imprisoned in the next few days because he continues to pose a threat to the Putin administration and frequently stages rallies and protests that often result in run-ins with the police.

On March 23, Putin appeared in a televised address to thank voters, ask for patience in achieving "real breakthrough," and took a swipe at Navalny by criticizing "irresponsible populism." 
One of Navalny's activists was detained by police for posting “extremist” memes online this week. Navalny continues to denounce Putin and Russian oligarchs and companies by name using his YouTube channel. He is still banned from Russian tv.
Highest probability was if it were to happen prior to election, now there is very little reason to.

Several interesting points in this article how (1) Putin co-opted the young who were starting to turn to Navalny (2) markedly increased GDP under Putin (not saying Putin’s policies led to that increase) (3) 28 million Russians have known no other leader (understand Medvedev had his strings pulled by Putin and (4) like youth everywhere they are connected via web/social media and savvier re. Consumption of state information.
http://www.economist.com/news/europe/21738902-those-who-have-known-only-vladimir-putin-dont-want-revolution-generation-has-known-only?frsc=dg%7Ce

He is actually to the right of Putin.  Putin won't treat him so harshly that  far right elements will become more energized against Putin--because much of Putin's support comes from the same quarters.
Why should Putin do this at this point and risk making Navalny a martyr?

Dropping a lot because I thought Navalny was going to be imprisoned before the election. I haven't read anything about him organizing protests in response to the election which is the usual reason to detain him post election.
Dropping it down significantly with the election over and no real incentive for Putin to drop another hammer on Navalny in the immediate future.

Still free as of 21 march.
Election over.
Opposition split.
His brother's treatment in jail is probably a way of keeping  him in line.
Why make him seem important now?
I think Navalny lost this round, probably nothing important will happen to him until the deadline.
-30.  More than one way to skin a cat - https://www.google.ca/search?q=navalny&rlz=1C1GGRV_enCA764CA764&source=lnms&tbm=nws&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwir5N3Ep_vZAhVG7qwKHccADsQQ_AUICigB&biw=1920&bih=900
The only reason to do this now would be to keep both him and the authorities in practice, or sheer nostalgia.  Neither needs practice, and nostalgia is overrated anyway.
If he didn't get arrested before the elections, what is the point of arresting him now unless he escalates his activism?  With the elections over, he'll get less attention.
I kept floating between 20 and 25%. Spilt the difference on the low side factoring in that with the killing aboard they might want things a bit calmer on the home front.
Staying with the consensus for now as I am unsure whether the result of the election makes it more or less likely. Hopefully will be able to make my mind up soon..

I guess a run off won’t be required ;). 74% of vote on 64% turnout TheiPhones and food didn’t get him to 70%, however.
Thinking that’s enough for him to avoid doing anything in next few weeks re. Navalny. 
Regarding “Election officials stuffing boxes with ballots”, how do we know those weren’t for opposition - Tsar Vlad the Shirtless is all about helping others.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43452449

To quick with submit. If I had known in advance I would vote a few times. My kids could use new phones...
https://themoscowtimes.com/news/young-russians-could-win-iphone-prizes-for-voting-60150

21 days left - keeping it low under assumption Navalny will be ignored. Arrest etc. Simply fuels Navalny and supporters plus feeds the current Russian news cycle given nerve agent issue in UK.
Agree with @dsarin. On way into work today BBC (radio) noted free meals for voters. Earlier iPhones provided to encourage turnout. Tsar Vlad the Shirtless wants to avoid complacency of non-voters. Recently saw something on BBC TV where ordinary Russians with conflicting views were afraid to be interviewed - like in so many banana republics.

Does murder count? Getting Novichok'd like Skripal (& his daughter) is kind of a chemically induced house arrest, well a hospital is home for the medically ill right? I can see the legal eagles parsing everything to resolve this if he is killed.

The lads in the Kremlin are shocked--shocked!--that he is trying to hold down turnout, not that it would matter.  They may pop him in the clink after the election just for old times' sake, but their current cunning plan of mostly just ignoring him and rounding up the other Usual Suspects will probably suffice for now.

Nalvany continues his activism unabated. Elections in Russia are this Sunday, March 18.  It's possible he may get detained before then as he continues to publicly denounce Putin. 
Just yesterday, Navalny called Britain to imposse targeted sanctions against oligarchs close to Vladimir Putin with assets in London. 
He tweeted today that law enforcement had raided one of his offices and confiscated pamphlets and other materials.
Putin is an increasingly paranoid thug, like Stalin.

Passage of time. It's all very much set (not like it wasn't before) but now Navalny seems to be quietening down. Deleting some tweets where he mocked May for 23 diplomats response for Skripal nerve agent poisoning. Perhaps Putina will just lay low also and cruise in.
AFAIK, no demonstrations are planned and on the election day Navalny is going to analyze election results. His supporters will monitor the election sites.
Russia has announced that Navalny is not eligible to run for election therefore there would be little benefit to jailing him since he can't run against Putin.
London situation likely to make Putin less tolerant of irritants.  Trial to be expedited as message
Looks increasingly like they're not going to bother with this for this round of fake voting, since Putin seems to have a comfy lead.

8 days until the (non) election. 4 weeks until the end of the question. From my perspective a crapshoot - as seen by divergent opinions. Does Tsar Vlad the Shirtless do the “usual”and have Navalny detained? That shows weakness and raises the issue internationally. Or does Tsar Vlad the Shirtless ignore Navalny even as latter does whatever he can via social media etc. to highlight how Vlad and his buddies have stolen billions from the state. I’m choosing Vlad trying to ignore Navalny. If only Navalny were a tiger Vlad could wrestle instead!

Downgraded to 55% with a month to go. It seems to make less and less sense for Putin to stir the pot with an antagonistic prison sentence for Navalny, as that could only provoke more opposition to Putin. Even if Navalny organizes loud anti-Putin demonstrations between now and the election, it won’t affect the election results. We know, and Putin knows, who will “win”.
No. Putin has  a ~80-90% percent popularity rate. He is not threatened. It's just another attempt from the west to bring down Putin.

Navalny isn't moving to England, so that should help his lifespan, but after this election, I think Navalny may be given time to consider his approach to social media etc..  http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43330498, @dsarin. (I am assuming 20 days will be adequate to trial and sentence for the crimes given).  Might track down a bit if Navalny doesnt provide court date in next 2 weeks)
Whatever 'Tsar Vlad the Shirtless' fanboys predict I'm going with the opposite ;-p
No longer a threat to Putin.  The outlying wildcard will be if Navalny is arrested for unrelated charges to his embezzlement conviction.

Alexei Navalny has already been detained in mid February however I extend this prediction to place an 60% chance that he will either be detained again or currently stay imprisoned from his previous arrest and unable to participate in the upcoming presidential election in Russia. The Russian authorities have been harassing Navalny for years and consistently stalk him in order to make sure his political protests cease to occur. Due to Navalny's persistent nature of protesting the Kremlin and opposing Putin, his opposition activities will not stop, even if Navalny might be imprisoned. His website and social media accounts have been shut down but he maintains a substantial following and his worldly recognition (and support) can be an added bonus.
I doubt Putin will allow him any of the spotlight through Election Day.
I think right now he is facing a 30-dayâ€‹ sentence.

I am more and more confident that this will not happen until the first election round. After 18 March Putin has no risk cracking down a large protest (if such a protest happens) and arrest the opposition leader. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-election-opposition-protests/anti-putin-protests-after-election-could-get-violent-opposition-warns-idUSKCN1GE1TY On the other hand, after the elections, Navalny will not be very threatening for Putin in any way, so I slightly decreased my prediction.

I’ve been all over on this one - from 100% to chance of extrajudicial means of removing Navalny from Tsar Vlad the Shirtless periphery. I realize there is paperwork underway and that question timing runs beyond election. Navalny WANTS to be arrested as seen by past events. He wants to be seen as focal point for opposition. Tsar Vlad is clever enough to realize this and much more. Believe Navalny will be hemmed in quietly if possible at this point. What better way to express power than ignoring “tangential” items and changing the discussion (new means of delivering nukes and new Shirtless photos). Like him or not you have to respect Tsar Vlad - he gets things done (even if it leads nowhere in medium to long term).

Arresting Navalny does Putin no good. Navalny is ineligible to run for political office due to his criminal conviction. Navalny has effectively been silenced: Putin controls all traditional media in Russia which only portray him negatively. Navalny's only method of mobilization is via the internet which Russia can minimize by manipulating social media. Placing him under house arrest increases his "martyrdom potential". Rather, Russia systematically harasses, arrests, and jails his Navalny's assistants - rendering him powerless. By allowing him to remain free, Putin can distract Russians from focusing on economic woes, military setbacks, and corruption.
Putin never leaves a stone unturned when it comes to political opponents.
i think it would have happened by now.
Not needed. Putin is still too popular.
I'm only at 90% because the Paperwork Error being blamed for his still being out of prison could turn into a Pedestrian accident of accidental fall etc.
Every possibility that he will be imprisoned( if he is lucky) or he will be assassinated by FSB.
Navalny now represents a movement of reform, accountability, transparency, fair elections, rule of law and clean government. He and his followers are a threat to the current Russian state.

Court delays, incorrect police report was drawn up
https://www.vesti.ru/doc.html?id=2991512
https://www.znak.com/2018-02-28/tverskoy_sud_moskvy_vernul_v_policiyu_administrativku_navalnogo
39 days left

Novalny is a business person with questionable reputation. Though the US administration tries to support him in order to shake the boot in Russia, in reality he has virtually no political base in Russia.
It's Russia and he's "asking for it".

Navalny Faces Jail Term After Latest Detention
https://themoscowtimes.com/news/navalny-faces-30-days-jail-after-latest-arrest-60607

Navalny has a court date on March 5th, and the possibility of being imprisoned for the Jan 28th protest. This would leave him in jail and unable to "make trouble" in the last weeks before the election. Otoh the Russian authorities might calculate that imprisoning him right beforer the election would bring more attention to his cause than he is able to generate on his own. If he is not jailed then the odds that he will be start to fall

Navalny has a hearing on March 5th and faces up to 30 days in jail for the Jan 28th protest.  I would go higher,  but it seems like the scale of these protests have been smaller than the 2011-2013 protests, and Putin may not view Navalny as a real threat.

Navalny tweeted that he had been detained by police on Thursday as he left a dental appointment. He was released just under an hour later, saying police had opened a case against him for organizing illegal protests.
He has already been neutralized by being disqualified from standing in elections

22 Feb - arrested and detained again, released same day - court case still pending with up to 30 day sentence attached
28 Jan - arrested and detained, released same day

With campaigns for Russian Presidential Election well under way, things are quite tense for candidates and other professionals opposed to Putin. Thursday, Navalny was arrested and detained for about an hour and threatened with a 30 imprisonment for his illegal protests. Given Navalny's previous imprisonment and consistent interference from the Russian government, it is evident that he is being targeted for opposing Putin's regime. With the official elections approaching in March and recent event, I now believe it is likely that Navalny will be imprisoned during the time of the election.
He might initiate illegal demonstrations to attract global attention in his efforts to encourage people to boycott the election.
He is out of elections anyway
He is a disturbing factor for the upcoming presidential elections held on March 18th

Just yesterday, Russian police detained Navalny and told him that he faces 30 days imprisonment for organizing illegal protests. According to Navalny, seven officers were sent to detain him, which is extremely excessive. I believe the government is trying to scare him out of the public light in order to quell his protests to election corruption in Russia. Navalny has been detained a number of times this year, and has proven to a thorn in the government's side. The nest step for Putin's regime would be to outright imprison him to show they are serious about arresting people that oppose them. Since the election is just a month away, Navalny is sure to step up is protests, leading to a higher chance of hi being imprisoned.

I think, it is very hard to predict, this is very much a game. Probably Putin's goal is to minimize Navalny's visibility, while Navalny wants the opposite - whatever it takes on both sides. This leads me to say, maybe he will not be imprisoned, as that would be big news, but there are two many hidden factors to be more sure.

Navalny will be arrested:
Pro:
1)	Always he was arrested when he was organized demonstrations
2)	He says he will be arrested
3)	Many experts says he will be arrested (100%)
4)	GJO inclined:  he will be arrested
5)	Variant: Navalny will be detained then released, he will go back to demonstration. Then will be arrest 
Con:
1)	he was not arrested after last his detention (more than 20 days after that violation), 53 days left, there are reasons for it from Putin (better arrest in early stage of violation, but they have time till election, they know it will be more violation if they arrest Navalny – partisans support him – and it will be more incentives to demonstrators)
2)	Government people switch attention to helpers of Navalny and ways of influence people
3)	Appearance of black swan may be (another ways to deal with Navalny - for example - sending on compulsory examination at a psychiatric hospital - or the decision of the opposition members to take active action after April 8 (they will not be able to prevent the elections anyway))
4)	Reducing power of Navalny 
5)	High results of polls for Putin
6)	Variant 2: Navalny will be detained then released, he will go back to demonstration.  He will again be detained for several hours, during this time all active assistants will be arrested

Putin will not tolerate the potential for Navalny to challenge his presumed victory by a declared large majority. Other candidates do not offer a similar threat due to lack of name recognition or small following.

Given that he is but an upstart, not on the ballot, in the eyes of the Kremlin, well, House arrest minimizes his presence in Public venues... More of a question is if his Social Media access will be restricted?

Navalny tweeted today that police had taken him into custody as he was coming out of a dentist's office, posting a picture of himself in a van with police officers.  He was detained for less than an hour.

CNN today reported that Navalny was briefly detained. It is also reporting that he could be spending the election in jail. However it is not clear whether or not he would be in jail because of serving a sentence, or because he is simply being detained.
li eble simple frapas kaj falos sur ia glacio aŭ iu alia tedaŭrinda evento

I acknowledge dsarin for always being on top of this...
I’ve been all over the map on this one. I thought he would be jailed with a potential for something extrajudicial. After his first detention in tv/radio studio I thought Tsar Vlad the Shirtless might leave him alone to portray how insignificant Navalny is. But with several detentions of others and starting legal process, it does appear he’s headed for the clink before March 18 vote.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/22/alexei-navalny-detained-moscow-russian-opposition-leader-faces-jail-election?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other

"Got a toothache, went to the dentist. came out of dentistry-'Hello, second operative Regiment, you are detained.' I'm beeing driven somewhere."
https://twitter.com/navalny/status/966619284658155520
Head of Navalny's campaign:
"I was detained at the airport (on the way to Ufa) , the second operative Regiment"
https://twitter.com/leonidvolkov/status/966611666178924544
atendos ĝis post elekto, tiam vidu ĉu lia juĝo rapide rapidas. Li ankoraŭ povas fali aŭ gliti sur iuj ŝtuparoj.
He continues to embarrass Putin and is challenging the anti democratic forces at work in the RF
His actions may get him jailed or placed under house arrest, but more likely for actions on his part, not as a political prisoner.
He is most likely to be put under administrative arrest. Nobody wants a rebel free and active during elections!

He personally can't take any actual votes away from Vlad the Shirtless, not being on the ballot and locking him up further reduces the pathetic shreds of legitimacy still clinging to Russian elections.  On the other hand, he does make Putin nervous.  When Putin gets nervous, people go to jail.  So still better than even money, I think, but edging down every day Navalny is at large.
I'd consider a 10% chance he will be killed.

Putin would endanger the appearance of a legitimate victory if Navalny is imprisoned before the upcoming Russian Presidential elections.  Navalny is already barred from running in the upcoming Presidential elections due to prior criminal convictions.  Questionable convictions, but convictions nonetheless.  Some discord among Navalny's supporters may take place in the time period surrounding the elections, but Putin will stick to his script that Navalny is a convicted criminal and was barred from participating in the election.  Ksenia Sobchak is now the candidate of change who is legally allowed to run for Russian President.  There is clear evidence her family has ties to Putin and she will likely quietly accept her defeat.  In my opinion, Navalny is now permanently irrelevant in Russian politics and Putin will probably win the actual vote count.
Putin hates dissent but doesn't want to raise ire of world as World Cup approaches.

Times is eroding this situation and it has become obvious to the Russian dictators that it is easier than they thought to hold their dictatorship powers. I am sure Navalny sees that it is fruitless to confront the dictators in their own turf without massive street demonstrations as he did in the past elections.
Russia needs open door strategy to US and Europe  because of probability of oil weakness and also football world cup and etc.
Adjusting down, the Russian election is about a month away.

In case there was any question about how Putin cleverly allows release of pressure...
http://www.economist.com/news/europe/21736541-unintended-puff-mr-putin-understanding-reality-tv-star-ksenia-sobchaks-presidential?frsc=dg%7Ce

Por ĉiu problemo, ĉiam estas solvo: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43034642. Ĉi tio pruvas, ke lia nomo ankoraŭ bedaŭras + 5, kvankam ili simple simple ignoras lin. Ili eble ankaŭ volas kondamni lin denove por ĉesi lin kurante (denove), kvankam verŝajne nur post ĉi tiuj elektoj tia, ke la elektoj ne konsideras murditaj, sed ankoraŭ eblas ene de la tempon de la demando. Mi pensas, ke ili provas ne martiri lin tamen, do restante sur la verŝajne jes, sed ne tute konvinkita flanko de jes.

Public support for Navalny does not register in the polls:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Russian_presidential_election,_2018
He was arrested on Jan 28th for participating in public protests and will continue to do so - Putin has shown little tolerance for dissent
Putin will easily win without this.
President Putin is trying his level best to win the election and he would like to show that he sidelined this competitor in a democratic way rather than eliminating him physically.

He's still calling for a boycott of the elections, said in an interview last week that "indications seem to be that I will be spending the election day, and I am referring to "election" in quotation marks, in a special prison. That's the plan, I suppose. On January 28, I was arrested and then immediately released. But I still haven't been given my papers back. Apparently, I've still got 30 days in jail ahead of me. It is probably planned that they will start on February 17, and then I will be released on March 18, 19 or 20."

Any real political threat to Putin from Navalny has been neutered successfully by preventing him from running. I don’t see any mass revolt
Or protest happening. Navalny had some good momentum but is fairly insignificant at the moment so no reason to arrest him.

It seems they have hesitated to put him in house arrest and he has disqualified himself from running, so other than a felonious action on his part,  he will not be house arrested . His actions are chaotic, however, and because of that are the percentages higher.
Depends if he keeps his mouth shut

Navalny is doing anything he can to be a thorn/get arrested. This may also lead to answer re conies dumped by Tsar Vlad the Shirtless. Regardless, what if Vlad does the “opposite” and ignores Navalny? That’s why I’m keeping it at 10%. Tsar Vlad looks weaker any time he tries to swat the fly that is Navalny (and misses).  
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/13/russian-watchdog-orders-youtube-to-remove-navalny-video
Historical narrative says that with elections coming up, although he isn't allowed to run, he will still be outspoken and the Kremlin can't allow that.
Putin fears any action from Navalny!

So they can imprison him on some trumped up charge but hold the court case later, say April 9th? The legalese and weasel words are getting silly. He's already been detained and released. So has the other candidate, the fmr St. Petersburg mayor/billionaire's daughter.
anybody who opposes putin ends up imprisoned or dead

As he is unable to run for office he does not serve as a direct threat to Putin's campaign. It is more likely he will be arrested if he chooses to protest during the elections but I suspect he would get a slap on the wrist as not to add to any popularity he has or to draw any further negative attention from the ECHR.
Putin always feels threatened by democratic forces (and rule of law) in Russia --and squirms if there is any uncertainty, even in a fixed, predetermined election.

Its RUSSIA!!!
I interpret the question as not a continuous detainment.
Putin needs to focus on newest competitors, Nevalny under house arrest will give him more space to do so.
If he isn't imprisoned or placed under house arrest on day 1, he's going to be more provocative on day 2, etc.

Alexey Navalny's  political stance - to discourage as many voters as possible not to go to the polling stations - is an unusual, albeit "permissible" act under Russian laws, which might gather momentum in the last 4 - 6 weeks leading up to the election date. Depending on Navalny's activism and forms of agitation the authorities might find themselves "obliged" to arrest him to prevent mass rallies propagating abstention from voting. On the other hand, if the authorities calculate that arresting Navalny would actually increase the number of abstentions, they will look for other means of reducing his influence on the Presidential election. This is why I rate the probability of arrest at 65%.
Because of the clarification question response of 2018-02-12.
The unrest has been going on for too long
Putin is capable of worse than imprisonment and will not brook interference in his re-election bid. And Navalny is no shrinking violet; he will be present wherever he can.
Overtly oppressing political opponents is bad PR.

Just as in the US, accusations of corruption, lack political legs, and the election is simply too close. Unless Mr. Navalny, causes mass protests, over something that the government does or doesn't do, then I believe that he'll be viewed as a nonissue.
he is not allowed to run for election. there are many other candidates running opposing Putin
It's hard to say.  It depends on the level of threat that Putin experiences and the ease of how he can deal with it.

I doubt it. Why should Putin do this? Navalny is already out of race for presidency.
The last time he called on his followers for demonstrations, even in the Western media there was little response. Navalny is probably no longer reported at all in Russia.
In addition, it is easier to murder a regime critic at large. If he were to die under house arrest, even Putin would be in need of explanations.
Putin jails his opposition if they are significant or if he can't rig the election.

He will be let go running. Putin will try to show this time, he is not afraid and actually, he can win. Therefore, there will be no arrests coming from him. By the way, your question lacks the clarity. What do you mean exactly by imprisoned? Do you take into consideration arrest and being let go after a day or two? Or do you mean long-term imprisonment? If you take into account short-term incarceration then the probability would be around 90%. I assume you don't take that into account.
His history with protest and of government reaction seems to guarantee some sort of detention
Based on the experience of others who have opposed Putin. He’s lucky he’s alive.

While the urge to arrest Navalny is there, placing him under house arrest might bring more people to follow his boycott of the election. This would go against Putin's wish for a large electoral turnout in order to give him an increased image of legitimacy. Navalny is therefore more likely to be ignored, rather than arrested.
While Putin considers him a troublemaker, the Russian opposition is weak enough to make Putin ignore Navalny.

I initially started low and then convinced myself that Navalny's arrest is an almost certainty. Now, I'm not so convinced. I think Putin's gotten what he wants - Navalny out of the race. And Navalny's detention demonstrated that the authorities can disrupt his activities without arresting him and angering his base.
There has been no hesitation to arrest him in the past. Barring him from the election has created additional tension. Navalny continues to publicly show his opposition to the Putin presidency.
Just the optics make this unlikely. They have other ways of limiting him.
Putin controls all things in Russia. He cotrols all things in the old GDR, noe the new eastern Germany.
There is no need unless Navalny starts a riot in the streets. The majority of Russian people do not know who he is/ Are afraid of the absence of Putin and his regime
Putin will continue to be weak and feel weak, and this will translate into action against his leading opponents.
He is too well known. They don't want to make him a hero by arresting him.
Detention but not arrested, more attention for helpers
Navalny is again in the press with new video release

I believe that Navalny has a high chance of being incarcerated during the Russian election period because obviously has been many times as stated in the description of the question, but at the same time this may be overkill since so many Russians truly do love Putin and Navalny's efforts will not necessarily win over many of their hearts, and even if he did, the Russian government is going make the election look like a landslide whether it truly was or not. So I only leave my answer at 80% because maybe the Russians will try and make an appeal to the international community that they are at least attempting to have a fair election, but those chances are slim considering their recent aggression on multiple fronts.
Navalny is too much of a threat to Putin and the United Russia party.
The government has prevented him from being on the ballot -- no reason to put him in jail or under house arrest.

While I acknowledge dsarin seems to be plugged in best (@ 100%) wondering if Navalny May be willing to wait until 2024? Seems to have a lot of organization behind him and his name is becoming more common. Thinking Tsar Vlad the Shirtless May be willing to mostly overlook him as a nuisance. He will work to build up org/base in 6 years.
Reducing to 10% while acknowledging he gets arrested with regularity!

Navalny's lifetime career goal has been to publicly highlight the immense corruption in the Russian political system and, is avidly opposed to Putin and his administration, which has resulted in his arrest more than one. Moreover, Navalny has vocalized his intent to run for office in the 2018 Russian presidential elections. Given the success of Navalny's platform and the potential threat this poses to Putin's regime, I expect that Navalny will at least be placed under house arrest for the time of the elections.
Mr. Putin has never believed much in free and fair elections, why would he start now.

Navalny himself realizes that government tactics most probably changed and he would be not imprisoned now or after he goes to SK (Russian equivalent of FBI). He is convinced that he would be imprisoned just at the time of elections, on March 18:

Given Alexei's continued agitation and the behavior in the past of Russia, I find it highly likely they will imprison him in the lead-up to the election on March 30th or immediately afterwards. They have already jailed his spokeswoman as a message but this did not appear to deter his behavior. International pressure does not seem to impact Russia much when it comes to domestic politics, and that pressure is currently lower than usual due to the Trump administration's "hands off" approach to Russia's domestic issues. The only reason this forecast is not higher is that it is possible that Russia will interpret his appeal as less threatening than past organizers who were able to get much larger crowds to protest against Putin, and he has already been ruled not a candidate for the election.

After the short detention this past weekend, the Russian election right around the corner, and the fury of the protests in city centers, plus the history that Putin has with his competition, I think he will be imprisoned leading up to the election. The regime does not need to risk internal and external legitimacy by such a move. They control the electoral machinery and other apparatuses so they can get the result they want without such "bush league" measures. Russia is not Venezuela, or at least that is the image they want to project. Putin wants Russia to have at least a basic appearance of rule of law, even thought that rule is abused and twisted by him and his cronies. Only if Navalny and his supporters force an existential crisis for the regime will major incarceration occur. If he presses to have a personal presence in this election any positive results will be declared null and void due to him being barred from running. Also, it is conceivable that he will work to get his supporters into office, not risk his personal status, and wait for either events to shift to a more favorable situation (perhaps due to his anti-corruption efforts) or for the next set of local and regional elections, perhaps even as long as the next Presidential election (assuming Putin is done by then).
